mainEntity.name: What are the different types of concrete mixes and their uses?

acceptedAnswer.text: Common concrete mixes include: (1) **Normal Strength (3000-4000 psi)**: Foundations and slabs (2) **High-Strength (5000+ psi)**: High-rise buildings (3) **Stamped**: Decorative patios (4) **Rapid-Set**: Repairs (sets in 1 hour) (5) **Fiber-Reinforced**: Crack-resistant driveways (6) **Lightweight**: Roof decks. Specialty mixes like pervious concrete allow water drainage for sustainable landscaping.

mainEntity.name: How long does concrete take to cure properly?

acceptedAnswer.text: Concrete reaches: (1) Walkable strength in 24-48 hours (2) 70% strength in 7 days (3) Full strength (3000+ psi) in 28 days. Critical first 48 hours require moist curing (spraying/wet burlap) to prevent cracks. Temperature affects timing - cold weather (below 50°F) can double curing time, while hot weather requires more frequent watering.

mainEntity.name: What precautions should be taken during concrete pouring?

acceptedAnswer.text: Essential precautions: (1) Check weather (avoid pouring below 40°F or in rain) (2) Prepare subgrade with compacted gravel (3) Use proper reinforcement (rebar or wire mesh) (4) Install formwork with 2x4 braces every 3 feet (5) Have enough workers for continuous pouring (cold joints weaken structure) (6) Keep curing blankets ready for temperature swings.

mainEntity.name: How to protect concrete surfaces from weather damage?

acceptedAnswer.text: Protection methods: (1) **Sealing**: Apply silane/siloxane sealer every 2-3 years (2) **Winter care**: Use calcium chloride instead of rock salt (3) **Sun protection**: UV-resistant coatings in hot climates (4) **Drainage**: Slope surfaces 1/4
space every 20 feet for thermal movement. For freeze-thaw areas, specify air-entrained concrete (4-6% air content).
